citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The facility has yet to develop a written program of veterinary care for the avian species on-hand at the facility. The
written program of veterinary care affirms both entities (facility and attending veterinarian) have a clear understanding of
their respective roles to provide appropriate care for the species housed. The facility should ensure that the written
program of veterinary care is available for review during all USDA inspections, with the documented arrangements to
include regularly scheduled visits to the premises of the facility.
Correct by March 26, 2024.

The Contingency plan available for review at the time of inspection was inadequate. The current plan describes facility
evacuation but does not list other reasonably anticipated emergencies or situations that trigger implementation of the
plan, the specific tasks/responsible person(s) for the tasks, the specific resources needed to perform the task, or how
response and recovery will be handled.
Per this section, exhibitors must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan for the humane handling, treatment,
transportation, housing, and care of their animals in the event of an emergency or disaster, one which could reasonably
be anticipated and expected to be detrimental to the health and well-being of the animals in their possession. The facility
shall ensure an adequate contingency plan is developed and followed in case of an emergency.
Correct by March 26, 2024.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
Although the facility provides enrichment to the birds, they do not have an environmental enhancement plan in place to
promote the overall psychological well-being of the birds at the facility. Exhibitors must develop, document, and follow a
species appropriate plan for environmental enhancement to promote the psychological wellbeing of the birds that is within
industry standards and approved by the veterinarian. The plan must be made available for future inspections.
Correct by March 26, 2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the Facility Representative.
n

narrative:
2.40 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The facility has yet to develop a written program of veterinary care for the avian species on-hand at the facility. The 
written program of veterinary care affirms both entities (facility and attending veterinarian) have a clear understanding of 
their respective roles to provide appropriate care for the species housed. The facility should ensure that the written 
program of veterinary care is available for review during all USDA inspections, with the documented arrangements to 
include regularly scheduled visits to the premises of the facility. 
 
Correct by March 26, 2024. 
2.134 
   
Contingency planning. 
The Contingency plan available for review at the time of inspection was inadequate. The current plan describes facility 
evacuation but does not list other reasonably anticipated emergencies or situations that trigger implementation of the 
plan, the specific tasks/responsible person(s) for the tasks, the specific resources needed to perform the task, or how 
response and recovery will be handled.  
 
Per this section, exhibitors must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan for the humane handling, treatment, 
transportation, housing, and care of their animals in the event of an emergency or disaster, one which could reasonably 
be anticipated and expected to be detrimental to the health and well-being of the animals in their possession. The facility 
shall ensure an adequate contingency plan is developed and followed in case of an emergency.  
 
Correct by March 26, 2024. 
3.154 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
Although the facility provides enrichment to the birds, they do not have an environmental enhancement plan in place to 
promote the overall psychological well-being of the birds at the facility. Exhibitors must develop, document, and follow a

species appropriate plan for environmental enhancement to promote the psychological wellbeing of the birds that is within 
industry standards and approved by the veterinarian. The plan must be made available for future inspections. 
 
Correct by March 26, 2024 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the Facility Representative.
